cleaned_text: COVID-19 |Coronavirus disease 2019| (COVID-19) |Other [Fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath, and supportive](/wiki/Management_of_COVID-19) Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a [contagious disease](/wiki/Contagious_disease) caused by the virus [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2). The first known case was [identified in Wuhan](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Hubei), China, in December 2019. [[6]](#cite_note-WSJ-20210226-6) The disease quickly spread worldwide, resulting in the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic). The [symptoms of COVID19](/wiki/Symptoms_of_COVID%E2%80%9119) are variable but often fever, [[7]](#cite_note-7) cough, headache, [[8]](#cite_note-8) fatigue, may begin one to fourteen days [after exposure](/wiki/Incubation_period) to the virus. At least a third of people who are infected [do not develop noticeable symptoms](/wiki/Asymptomatic). [[12]](#cite_note-12) Of those who develop symptoms noticeable enough to be classified as patients, most (81%) develop mild to moderate symptoms (up to mild [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia)), while 14% develop severe symptoms ( [dyspnea](/wiki/Dyspnea), [hypoxia](/wiki/Hypoxia_(medical)), or more than 50% lung involvement on imaging), and 5% develop critical symptoms ( [respiratory failure](/wiki/Respiratory_failure), [shock](/wiki/Shock_(circulatory)), or [multiorgan dysfunction](/wiki/Organ_dysfunction)). [[13]](#cite_note-CDC_Interim_Guidance-13) Older people are at a higher risk of developing severe symptoms. Some people continue to experience a range of effects ( [long COVID](/wiki/Long_COVID)) for years after infection, and damage to organs has been observed. [[14]](#cite_note-davis-14) Multi-year studies are underway to further investigate the long-term effects of the disease. [[15]](#cite_note-:5-15) [COVID19 transmits](/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19) when infectious particles are breathed in or come into contact with the eyes, nose, or mouth. The risk is highest when people are in close proximity, but small [airborne](/wiki/Airborne_transmission) particles containing the virus can remain suspended in the air and travel over longer distances, particularly indoors. Transmission can also occur when people touch their eyes, nose or mouth after touching surfaces or objects that have been contaminated by the virus. People remain contagious for up to 20 days and can spread the virus even if they do not develop symptoms. [[16]](#cite_note-16) [Testing methods for COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19_testing) to detect the virus's vaccines](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine) have been approved and distributed in various countries, which have initiated [mass vaccination campaigns](/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines). Other [preventive measures](/wiki/Pandemic_prevention) include [physical or social distancing](/wiki/Social_distancing), [quarantining](/wiki/Quarantine), ventilation of indoor spaces, [use of face masks or coverings](/wiki/Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic) in public, covering coughs and sneezes, [hand washing](/wiki/Hand_washing), and keeping unwashed hands away from the face. While work is underway to [develop drugs](/wiki/COVID-19_drug_development) that inhibit the virus, the primary [treatment](/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19) is symptomatic. Management involves the [treatment of symptoms](/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment) through [supportive care](/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment), [isolation](/wiki/Isolation_(health_care)), and [experimental measures](/wiki/Medical_research). Nomenclature During the initial outbreak in [Wuhan](/wiki/Wuhan), the virus and disease were commonly referred to as "coronavirus" and "Wuhan coronavirus", [[21]](#cite_note-21) pneumonia". [[24]](#cite_note-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) In the past, many diseases have been named after geographical locations, such as the [Spanish flu](/wiki/Spanish_flu), [[26]](#cite_note-26) [Middle East respiratory Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) recommended 2019-nCoV [[28]](#cite_note-28) and 2019-nCoV acute respiratory disease [[29]](#cite_note-29) as interim names for the virus and disease per 2015 guidance and international guidelines against using geographical locations or groups of people in disease and virus names to prevent [social stigma](/wiki/Social_stigma). [[30]](#cite_note-30) [[31]](#cite_note-veconomist-31) [[32]](#cite_note-32) The official names COVID19 and SARS-CoV-2 were issued by the WHO on 11 February 2020 with COVID-19 being shorthand for "coronavirus disease 2019". [[33]](#cite_note-WHO-naming-33) [[34]](#cite_note-34) The WHO additionally virus" virus responsible for COVID19" in public communications. [[33]](#cite_note-WHO-naming-33) [[35]](#cite_note-35) Symptoms and signs The [symptoms](/wiki/Symptom) of COVID-19 are variable depending on the type of variant contracted, ranging from mild symptoms to a potentially fatal illness. [[36]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC2020Sym-36) [[37]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Grant_et_al_2020-37) Common symptoms or turning purple, [[39]](#cite_note-39) and in moderate to severe cases, [breathing difficulties](/wiki/Breathing_difficulties). [[40]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_ECDC-40) People with the COVID-19 infection may have different symptoms, and their symptoms may change over time. Three common clusters of symptoms have been identified: one respiratory symptom cluster with cough, [sputum](/wiki/Sputum), [shortness of breath](/wiki/Shortness_of_breath), and fever; a musculoskeletal symptom cluster with [muscle](/wiki/Skeletal_muscle) and joint pain, headache, and fatigue; and a cluster of digestive symptoms with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. [[40]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_ECDC-40) In people without prior ear, nose, or throat disorders, [loss of taste](/wiki/Hypogeusia) combined with [loss of smell](/wiki/Hyposmia) is associated with COVID-19 and is reported in as many as 88% of symptomatic cases. [[41]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Paderno_2020-41) [[42]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Chabot_2021-42) [[43]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32483687-43) Of people who show symptoms, 81% develop only mild to moderate symptoms (up to mild [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia)), while 14% develop severe symptoms ( [dyspnea](/wiki/Dyspnea), [hypoxia](/wiki/Hypoxia_(medical)), or more than 50% lung involvement on imaging) that require hospitalization, and 5% of patients develop critical symptoms ( [respiratory failure](/wiki/Respiratory_failure), [[44]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC_Interim_Guidance-44)[ [needs update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items)] At least a third of the people who are infected with the virus do not develop noticeable symptoms at any point in time. [[45]](#cite_note-45) [[46]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Asymptomatic-46) These [asymptomatic](/wiki/Asymptomatic) carriers tend not to get tested and can still spread the disease. [[46]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Asymptomatic-46) [[47]](#cite_note-47) [[48]](#cite_note-48) [[49]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Furukawa_2020-49) Other infected people will develop symptoms later (called "pre-symptomatic") or have very mild symptoms and can also spread the virus. [[49]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_Furukawa_2020-49) As is common with infections, there is [a delay](/wiki/Incubation_period) between the moment a person first becomes infected and the appearance of the first symptoms. The [median](/wiki/Median) delay for COVID-19 is four to five days [[50]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32329974-50) possibly being infectious on 1-4 of those days. [[51]](#cite_note-51) Most symptomatic people experience symptoms within two to seven days after exposure, and almost all will experience at least one symptom within 12 days. [[50]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_pmid32329974-50) [[52]](#cite_note-52) Most people recover from the [acute](/wiki/Acute_(medicine)) phase of the disease. However, some people continue to experience a range of effects, such as [fatigue](/wiki/Fatigue), for months, even after recovery. [[53]](#cite_note-53) This is the result of a condition called [long COVID](/wiki/Long_COVID), which can be described as a range of persistent symptoms that continue for weeks or months at a time. [[54]](#cite_note-Symptoms_of_COVID-19_CDC_2022-54) Long-term damage to organs has also been observed after the onset of COVID-19. Multi-year studies are underway to further investigate the potential long-term effects of the disease. [[55]](#cite_note-55) [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant)became dominant in the U.S. in December 2021. Symptoms with the Omicron variant are less severe than they are with other variants. [[56]](#cite_note-56) Complications Complications may [elevated liver enzymes](/wiki/Elevated_transaminases), reflecting liver injury. [loss of motor functions](/wiki/Hemiparesis)). [[70]](#cite_note-70) the infection, children may develop [paediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome](/wiki/Paediatric_multisystem_inflammatory_syndrome), which has symptoms similar to [Kawasaki disease](/wiki/Kawasaki_disease), which can be fatal. [[71]](#cite_note-71) [[72]](#cite_note-72) In very rare cases, acute [encephalopathy](/wiki/Encephalopathy) can occur, and it can be considered in those who have been diagnosed with COVID19 and have an altered mental status. [[73]](#cite_note-73) According to the US [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention), pregnant women are at increased risk of becoming seriously ill from COVID19. [[74]](#cite_note-:17-74) This is because pregnant women with COVID19 appear to be more likely to develop respiratory and obstetric complications that can lead to [miscarriage](/wiki/Miscarriage), [premature delivery](/wiki/Premature_delivery) [candidiasis](/wiki/Candidiasis), [cryptococcosis](/wiki/Cryptococcosis) and been recorded in patients recovering from COVID19. [[75]](#cite_note-75) [[76]](#cite_note-76) Cause COVID19 is caused by infection with a [strain](/wiki/Strain_(biology)#Microbiology_and_virology) of [coronavirus](/wiki/Coronavirus) known as 'Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus 2' ( [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2)). [[77]](#cite_note-77) Transmission COVID-19 is mainly transmitted when people breathe in air contaminated by [droplets](/wiki/Drop_(liquid))/ [aerosols](/wiki/Aerosol) and small [airborne](/wiki/Airborne_transmission) particles containing the virus. Infected people exhale those particles as they breathe, talk, cough, sneeze, or sing. [[78]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Wang_2021-78) [[79]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Greenhalgh_2021-79) [[80]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_AR2021-80) [[81]](#cite_note-81) Transmission is more likely the closer people are. However, infection can occur over longer distances, particularly indoors. [[78]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Wang_2021-78) [[82]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Miller_2021-82) The transmission of the virus is carried out through virus-laden fluid particles, or droplets, which are created in the respiratory tract, and they are expelled by the mouth and the nose. There are three types of transmission: "droplet" and "contact", which are associated with large droplets, and "airborne", which is associated with small droplets. [[83]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_:1-83) If the droplets are above a certain critical size, they settle faster than they [evaporate](/wiki/Evaporate), and therefore they [contaminate](/wiki/Contaminate) surfaces surrounding them. [[83]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_:1-83) Droplets that are below a certain critical size, evaporate faster than they settle; due to that fact, they form nuclei that remain airborne for a long period of time over extensive distances. [[83]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_:1-83) Infectious particles range in size from [Infectivity](/wiki/Infectivity) can begin four to five days before the onset of symptoms. [[84]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_HeCorrection-84) Infected people can spread the disease even if they are pre-symptomatic or [asymptomatic](/wiki/Asymptomatic). [[85]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_CDNASoNG-85) Most commonly, the peak viral load in [upper respiratory tract](/wiki/Upper_respiratory_tract) samples occurs close to the time of symptom onset and declines after the first week after symptoms begin. [[85]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_CDNASoNG-85) Current evidence suggests a duration of viral shedding and the period of infectiousness of up to ten days following symptom onset for people with mild to moderate COVID-19, and up to 20 days for persons with severe COVID-19, including immunocompromised people. [[86]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_CDCClinicalQuestions-86) [[85]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_CDNASoNG-85) [aerosols](/wiki/Aerosol)that remain suspended in the air for long periods of time to larger [droplets](/wiki/Respiratory_droplet)that remain airborne briefly or fall to the ground. [[87]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_CDCScientificBriefTransmission-87) [[88]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_who_transmitted-88) [[89]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_WHO-ECDC-CDC-UK-Ca-Aus-Annals-89) [[90]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Tang_2021-90)Additionally, COVID-19 research has redefined the traditional understanding of how respiratory viruses are transmitted. [[90]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Tang_2021-90) [[91]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Morawska_2021-91)The largest droplets of respiratory fluid do not travel far, but can be inhaled or land on mucous membranes on the eyes, nose, or mouth to infect. [[89]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_WHO-ECDC-CDC-UK-Ca-Aus-Annals-89)Aerosols are highest in concentration when people are in close proximity, which leads to easier viral transmission when people are physically close, [[89]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_WHO-ECDC-CDC-UK-Ca-Aus-Annals-89) [[90]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Tang_2021-90) [[91]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_Morawska_2021-91)but [airborne transmission](/wiki/Airborne_transmission)can occur at longer distances, mainly in locations that are poorly ventilated; [[89]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_WHO-ECDC-CDC-UK-Ca-Aus-Annals-89)in those conditions small particles can remain suspended in the air for minutes to hours. [[89]](#cite_note-Transmission_of_COVID-19_WHO-ECDC-CDC-UK-Ca-Aus-Annals-89) [[92]](#cite_note-92) Virology Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is a [novel](/wiki/Novel_virus) severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus. It was first isolated from three people with pneumonia connected to the [cluster](/wiki/Disease_cluster) of acute respiratory illness cases in Wuhan. [[93]](#cite_note-ECDC_risk_assessment-93) All structural features of the novel SARS-CoV-2 virus particle occur in related [coronaviruses](/wiki/Coronavirus) in nature, [[94]](#cite_note-NM-20200317-94) particularly in [Rhinolophus sinicus](/wiki/Rhinolophus_sinicus) aka Chinese horseshoe bats. [[95]](#cite_note-zhou20-95) Outside the human body, the virus is destroyed by household soap which bursts its [protective bubble](/wiki/Viral_envelope). [[96]](#cite_note-NatGeoSoap-96) Hospital disinfectants, alcohols, heat, [povidone-iodine](/wiki/Povidone-iodine), and [ultraviolet-C](/wiki/Ultraviolet) (UV-C) irradiation are also effective disinfection methods for surfaces. [[97]](#cite_note-97) SARS-CoV-2 is closely related to the original [SARS-CoV](/wiki/SARS-CoV). [[98]](#cite_note-Zhu24Jan2020-98) It is thought to have an animal ( [zoonotic](/wiki/Zoonosis)) origin. Genetic analysis has revealed that the coronavirus genetically clusters with the genus [Betacoronavirus](/wiki/Betacoronavirus), in subgenus [Sarbecovirus](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome%E2%80%93related_coronavirus) (lineage B) together with two bat-derived strains. It is 96% identical at the whole [genome](/wiki/Genome) level to other bat coronavirus samples (BatCov [RaTG13](/wiki/RaTG13)). [spike protein](/wiki/Coronavirus_spike_protein) (S). The M protein of SARS-CoV-2 is about 98% similar to the M protein of bat SARS-CoV, maintains around 98% homology with pangolin SARS-CoV, and has 90% homology with the M protein of SARS-CoV; whereas, the similarity is only around 38% with the M protein of MERS-CoV. [[102]](#cite_note-102) SARS-CoV-2 variants The many thousands of into either [clades](/wiki/Clade) or [lineages](/wiki/Lineage_(evolution)). [[103]](#cite_note-103) [[104]](#cite_note-:21-104) The WHO, in collaboration with partners, expert networks, national authorities, institutions and researchers, have established nomenclature systems for naming and tracking SARS-CoV-2 genetic lineages by [GISAID](/wiki/GISAID), [Nextstrain](/wiki/Nextstrain) and [Pango](/wiki/Phylogenetic_Assignment_of_Named_Global_Outbreak_Lineages). The expert group convened by the WHO recommended the labelling of variants using letters of the [Greek alphabet](/wiki/Greek_alphabet), for example, [Alpha](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Alpha_variant), [Beta](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Beta_variant), [Delta](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant), and [Gamma](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Gamma_variant), giving the justification that they "will be easier and more practical to discussed by non-scientific audiences." [[105]](#cite_note-105) [Nextstrain](/wiki/Nextstrain) and 20C), while [GISAID](/wiki/GISAID) divides them into seven (L, O, V, S, G, GH, and GR). [[106]](#cite_note-Alm2020Aug-106) The Pango tool groups variants into [lineages](/wiki/Lineage_(evolution)), with many circulating lineages being classed under the B.1 lineage. [[104]](#cite_note-:21-104) [[107]](#cite_note-107) Several notable [[109]](#cite_note-Abdool_Karim_de_Oliveira_pp._1866-1868-109) [Cluster among and mink farmers in [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark). [[110]](#cite_note-110) After strict quarantines and a mink euthanasia campaign, the cluster was assessed to no longer be circulating among humans in Denmark as of 1 February 2021. [[111]](#cite_note-111) As of December 2021 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19&action=edit), there are five dominant variants of SARS-CoV-2 spreading among global populations: the [Alpha variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Alpha_variant) (B.1.1.7, formerly called the UK variant), first found in London and Kent, the [Beta variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Beta_variant) (B.1.351, formerly called the South Africa variant), the [Gamma variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Gamma_variant) (P.1, formerly called the Brazil variant), the [Delta variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant) (B.1.617.2, formerly called the India variant), [[112]](#cite_note-112) and the [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant) (B.1.1.529), which had spread to 57 countries as of 7 December. [[113]](#cite_note-113) [[114]](#cite_note-114) Pathophysiology The SARS-CoV-2 virus can infect a wide range of cells and systems of the body. COVID19 is most known for affecting the upper respiratory tract (sinuses, nose, and throat) and the lower respiratory tract (windpipe and lungs). [[115]](#cite_note-pmid33132005-115) The lungs are the organs most affected by COVID19 because the virus accesses host cells via the [receptor](/wiki/Receptor_(biochemistry)) for the enzyme [angiotensin-converting enzyme 2](/wiki/Angiotensin-converting_enzyme_2) (ACE2), which is abundant on the surface of [type II alveolar cells](/wiki/Type_II_cell) of the lungs. [[116]](#cite_note-116) The virus uses a special surface glycoprotein called a " [spike](/wiki/Coronavirus_spike_protein)" to connect to the ACE2 receptor and enter the host cell. [[117]](#cite_note-Nature_Microbiology-117) Respiratory tract Following viral entry, COVID19 infects the ciliated epithelium of the nasopharynx and upper airways. [[118]](#cite_note-118) Nervous system One common symptom, loss of smell, results from [infection of the support cells of the olfactory epithelium](/wiki/Impact_of_COVID-19_on_neurological,_psychological_and_other_mental_health_outcomes), with subsequent damage to the [olfactory neurons](/wiki/Olfactory_receptor_neuron). [[119]](#cite_note-:15-119) The involvement of both the central and peripheral nervous system in COVID19 has been reported in many medical publications. [[120]](#cite_note-Guerrero2020-120) It is clear that many people with [COVID-19 exhibit neurological or mental health issues](/wiki/Impact_of_COVID-19_on_neurological,_psychological_and_other_mental_health_outcomes). The virus is not detected in the [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system) (CNS) of the majority of COVID-19 patients with [neurological issues](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_neurological,_psychological_and_other_mental_health_outcomes). However, SARS-CoV-2 has been detected at low levels in the brains of those who have died from COVID19, but these results need to be confirmed. [[121]](#cite_note-Pezzini2020-121) While virus has been detected in [cerebrospinal fluid](/wiki/Cerebrospinal_fluid) of autopsies, the exact mechanism by which it invades the CNS remains unclear and may first involve invasion of peripheral nerves given the low levels of ACE2 in the brain. [[122]](#cite_note-122) [[123]](#cite_note-123) [[124]](#cite_note-124) The virus may also enter the bloodstream from the lungs and cross the blood-brain barrier to gain access to the CNS, possibly within an infected white blood cell. [[121]](#cite_note-Pezzini2020-121) Research conducted when Alpha was the dominant variant has suggested COVID-19 may cause brain damage. [[125]](#cite_note-125) It is unknown if such damage is temporary or permanent, and whether Omicron has similar effects. [[126]](#cite_note-126) [[127]](#cite_note-127) Observed individuals infected with COVID-19 (most with mild cases) experienced an additional 0.2% to 2% of brain tissue lost in regions of the brain connected to the sense of smell compared with uninfected individuals, and the overall effect on the brain was equivalent on average to at least one extra year of normal ageing; infected individuals also scored lower on several cognitive tests. All effects were more pronounced among older ages. [[128]](#cite_note-128) Gastrointestinal tract The virus also affects gastrointestinal organs as ACE2 is abundantly expressed in the [glandular](/wiki/Gland) cells of [gastric](/wiki/Stomach), [duodenal](/wiki/Duodenum) and [rectal](/wiki/Rectum) [epithelium](/wiki/Epithelium) [[129]](#cite_note-:11-129) [enterocytes](/wiki/Enterocyte) of the [small intestine](/wiki/Small_intestine). [[130]](#cite_note-pmid32343593-130) Cardiovascular system The virus can cause [acute and chronic damage to the [cardiovascular system](/wiki/Circulatory_system). [[131]](#cite_note-131) [[132]](#cite_note-:3-132) An acute cardiac injury was found in 12% of infected people admitted to the hospital in Wuhan, China, [[133]](#cite_note-Huang24Jan2020-133) and is more frequent in severe disease. [[134]](#cite_note-134) Rates of cardiovascular symptoms are high, owing to the systemic inflammatory response and immune system disorders during disease progression, but acute myocardial injuries may also be related to ACE2 receptors in the heart. [[132]](#cite_note-:3-132) ACE2 receptors are highly expressed in the heart and are involved in heart function. [[132]](#cite_note-:3-132) [[135]](#cite_note-135) A high incidence of [thrombosis](/wiki/Thrombosis) and [venous thromboembolism](/wiki/Venous_thromboembolism) occurs in people transferred to [intensive care units](/wiki/Intensive_care_unit) with COVID19 infections, and may be related to poor prognosis. [[136]](#cite_note-136) Blood vessel dysfunction and clot formation (as suggested by high [D-dimer](/wiki/D-dimer) levels caused by blood clots) may have a significant role in mortality, incidents of clots leading to [pulmonary embolisms](/wiki/Pulmonary_embolism), and [ischaemic events](/wiki/Stroke) (strokes) within the brain found as complications leading to death in people infected with COVID19. [[137]](#cite_note-Science-137) Infection may initiate a chain of [vasoconstrictive responses](/wiki/Vasoconstriction) within the body, including pulmonary vasoconstriction - a possible mechanism in which oxygenation decreases during pneumonia. [[137]](#cite_note-Science-137) Furthermore, damage of [arterioles](/wiki/Arterioles) and [capillaries](/wiki/Capillaries) was found in brain tissue samples of people who died from COVID19. [[138]](#cite_note-138) [[139]](#cite_note-139) COVID19 may also cause substantial structural changes to [blood cells](/wiki/Blood_cell), sometimes persisting for months after hospital discharge. [[140]](#cite_note-140) [A low level of blood lymphocytes](/wiki/Lymphopenia) may result from the virus acting through ACE2-related entry into lymphocytes. [[141]](#cite_note-141) Other organs Another common cause of death is complications related to the [kidneys](/wiki/Kidney). [[137]](#cite_note-Science-137) Early reports show that up to 30% of hospitalised patients both in China and in New York have experienced some injury to their kidneys, including some persons with no previous kidney problems. [[142]](#cite_note-142) Autopsies of people who died of COVID19 have found [diffuse alveolar damage](/wiki/Diffuse_alveolar_damage), and Although SARS-CoV-2 has a tropism for ACE2-expressing epithelial cells of the respiratory tract, people with severe COVID19 have symptoms of systemic hyperinflammation. Clinical laboratory immunopathology. [[133]](#cite_note-Huang24Jan2020-133) [Interferon alpha](/wiki/Interferon-alpha) plays a complex, Janus-faced role in the pathogenesis of COVID-19. Although it promotes the elimination of virus-infected cells, it also upregulates the expression of ACE-2, thereby facilitating the SARS-Cov2 virus to enter cells and to replicate. [[144]](#cite_note-144) [[145]](#cite_note-145) A competition of negative feedback loops (via protective effects of interferon alpha) and positive feedback loops (via upregulation of ACE-2) is assumed to determine the fate of patients suffering from COVID-19. [[146]](#cite_note-146) Additionally, people with COVID19 and [acute respiratory distress syndrome](/wiki/Acute_respiratory_distress_syndrome) (ARDS) have [vasodilation](/wiki/Vasodilation), allowing inflammatory lymphocytic and monocytic infiltration of the lung and the heart. In particular, pathogenic GM-CSF-secreting [T cells](/wiki/T_cell) were shown to correlate with the recruitment of inflammatory IL-6-secreting [monocytes](/wiki/Monocyte) and severe lung pathology in people with COVID19. [[148]](#cite_note-148) Lymphocytic infiltrates have also been reported at autopsy. [[143]](#cite_note-Cureus-143) Viral and host factors Virus proteins Multiple viral and host factors affect the pathogenesis of the virus. The S-protein, otherwise known as the spike protein, is the viral component that attaches to the host receptor via the [ACE2](/wiki/Angiotensin-converting_enzyme_2) receptors. It includes two subunits: S1 and S2. S1 determines the virus-host tropism via the receptor-binding domain. S2 mediates the membrane fusion of the virus to its potential cell host via the H1 and HR2, which are [heptad repeat](/wiki/Heptad_repeat) regions. Studies have shown that S1 domain induced [IgG](/wiki/IgG) and [IgA](/wiki/IgA) antibody levels at a much higher capacity. It is the focus spike proteins expression that are involved in many effective COVID19 vaccines. [[149]](#cite_note-pmid33340022-149) The M protein is the viral protein responsible for the transmembrane transport of nutrients. It is the cause of the bud release and the formation of the viral envelope. [[150]](#cite_note-:6-150) The N and E protein are accessory proteins that interfere with the host's immune response. [[150]](#cite_note-:6-150) Host factors Human [angiotensin converting enzyme 2](/wiki/Angiotensin_converting_enzyme_2) (hACE2) is the host factor that SARS-CoV-2 virus targets causing COVID19. Theoretically, the usage of [angiotensin receptor blockers](/wiki/Angiotensin_II_receptor_blocker) (ARB) and inhibitors](/wiki/ACE_inhibitor) upregulating ACE2 expression might increase [morbidity](/wiki/Morbidity) with COVID19, though animal data suggest some potential protective effect of ARB; however no clinical studies have proven susceptibility or outcomes. Until further data is available, guidelines and recommendations for hypertensive patients remain. [[151]](#cite_note-151) The effect of the virus on ACE2 cell surfaces leads to leukocytic infiltration, increased blood vessel permeability, alveolar wall permeability, as well as decreased secretion of lung surfactants. These effects cause the majority of the respiratory symptoms. However, the aggravation of local inflammation causes a cytokine storm eventually leading to a [systemic inflammatory response syndrome](/wiki/Systemic_inflammatory_response_syndrome). [[152]](#cite_note-152) Among healthy adults not exposed to SARS-CoV-2, about 35% have [CD4+ T cells](/wiki/CD4%2B_T_cell) [S protein](/wiki/Peplomer) (particularly the S2 subunit) and about 50% react to other proteins of the virus, suggesting [cross-reactivity](/wiki/Cross-reactivity) from previous [common colds](/wiki/Common_cold) caused by other coronaviruses. [[153]](#cite_note-153) It is unknown whether different persons use similar antibody genes in response to COVID19. [[154]](#cite_note-154) Host cytokine response The severity of the inflammation can be attributed to the severity of what is known as the [cytokine storm](/wiki/Cytokine_storm). [[155]](#cite_note-pmid32474885-155) Levels monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 were all associated with COVID19 disease severity. Treatment has been proposed to combat the cytokine storm as it remains to be one of the leading causes of [morbidity](/wiki/Morbidity) and mortality in COVID19 disease. [[156]](#cite_note-156) A cytokine storm is due to an acute hyperinflammatory response that is responsible for clinical illness in an array of diseases but in COVID19, it is related to worse prognosis and increased fatality. The storm causes acute respiratory distress syndrome, blood clotting events such as strokes, myocardial infarction, [encephalitis](/wiki/Encephalitis), [acute [IL-6](/wiki/Interleukin_6), [TNF-alpha](/wiki/Tumor_necrosis_factor), and [interferon-gamma](/wiki/Interferon_gamma), all crucial components of normal immune responses, inadvertently become the causes of a cytokine storm. The cells of the [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system), the [microglia](/wiki/Microglia), [neurons](/wiki/Neuron), and [astrocytes](/wiki/Astrocyte), are also involved in the release of [pro-inflammatory cytokines](/wiki/Pro-inflammatory_cytokine) affecting the nervous system, and effects of cytokine storms toward the [CNS](/wiki/Central_nervous_system) are not uncommon. [[157]](#cite_note-157) Pregnancy response There are many unknowns for pregnant women during the COVID-19 pandemic. Given that they are prone to have complications and severe disease infection with other types of coronaviruses, they have been identified as a vulnerable group and advised to take supplementary preventive measures. [[158]](#cite_note-Wastnedge_2021-158) Physiological responses to pregnancy can include: - Immunological: The immunological response to COVID-19, like other viruses, depends on a working immune system. It adapts during pregnancy to allow the development of the foetus whose genetic load is only partially shared with their mother, leading to a different immunological reaction to infections during the course of pregnancy. [[158]](#cite_note-Wastnedge_2021-158) - Respiratory: Many factors can make pregnant women more vulnerable to hard respiratory infections. One of them is the total reduction of the lungs' capacity and inability to clear secretions. [[158]](#cite_note-Wastnedge_2021-158) - Coagulation: During pregnancy, there are higher levels of circulating coagulation factors, and the pathogenesis of SARS-CoV-2 infection can be implicated. The thromboembolic events with associated mortality are a risk for pregnant women. [[158]](#cite_note-Wastnedge_2021-158) However, from the evidence base, it is difficult to conclude whether pregnant women are at increased risk of grave consequences of this virus. [[158]](#cite_note-Wastnedge_2021-158) In addition to the above, other clinical studies have proved that SARS-CoV-2 can affect the period of pregnancy in different ways. On the one hand, there is little evidence of its impact up to 12 weeks gestation. On the other hand, COVID-19 infection may cause increased rates of unfavourable outcomes in the course of the pregnancy. Some examples of these could be foetal growth restriction, preterm birth, and perinatal mortality, which refers to the foetal death past 22 or 28 completed weeks of pregnancy as well as the death among live-born children up to seven completed days of life. [[158]](#cite_note-Wastnedge_2021-158) For preterm birth, a 2023 review indicates that there appears to be a correlation with COVID-19. [[159]](#cite_note-159) Unvaccinated women in later stages of pregnancy with COVID-19 are more likely than other patients to need very intensive care. Babies born to mothers with COVID-19 are more likely to have breathing problems. Pregnant women are strongly encouraged to get [vaccinated](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine). [[160]](#cite_note-160) Diagnosis COVID19 can provisionally be diagnosed on the basis of symptoms and confirmed using [reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction](/wiki/Reverse_transcription_polymerase_chain_reaction) (RT-PCR) or other [nucleic acid](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test) testing of infected secretions. [[20]](#cite_note-pmid32621814-20) [[161]](#cite_note-jTxKm-161) Along with laboratory testing, chest CT scans may be helpful to diagnose COVID19 in individuals with a high clinical suspicion of infection. [[162]](#cite_note-:0-162) Detection of a past infection is possible with [serological tests](/wiki/Serology), which detect [antibodies](/wiki/Antibody) produced by the body in response to the infection. [[20]](#cite_note-pmid32621814-20) Viral testing The standard methods of testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 are [nucleic acid tests](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test), [[20]](#cite_note-pmid32621814-20) [[163]](#cite_note-20200130cdc-163) which detects the presence of viral RNA fragments. [[164]](#cite_note-WHO_InterimGuidance-164) As these tests detect RNA but not infectious virus, its "ability to determine duration of infectivity of patients is limited." [[165]](#cite_note-2k0iS-165) The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a [nasopharyngeal swab](/wiki/Nasopharyngeal_swab); however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used. [[166]](#cite_note-CDC2020Testing-166) [[167]](#cite_note-20200129cdc-167) Results are generally available within hours. [[20]](#cite_note-pmid32621814-20) The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease. [[168]](#cite_note-168) Several laboratories and companies have developed serological tests, which detect antibodies produced by the body in response to infection. Several have been evaluated by [Public Health England](/wiki/Public_Health_England) and approved for use in the UK. [[169]](#cite_note-independent9515466-169) The [University of Oxford](/wiki/University_of_Oxford)'s CEBM has pointed to mounting evidence [[170]](#cite_note-yFMEP-170) [[171]](#cite_note-2exX5-171) that "a good proportion of 'new' mild cases and people re-testing positives after quarantine or discharge from hospital are not infectious, but are simply clearing harmless virus particles which their immune system has efficiently dealt with" and have called for "an international effort to standardize and periodically calibrate testing" [[172]](#cite_note-PQGAv-172) In September 2020, the UK government issued "guidance for procedures to be implemented in laboratories to provide assurance of positive SARS-CoV-2 RNA results during periods of low prevalence, when there is a reduction in the predictive value of positive test results". [[173]](#cite_note-9Kblp-173) Imaging Chest CT scans may be helpful to diagnose COVID19 in individuals with a high clinical suspicion of infection but are not recommended for routine screening. [[162]](#cite_note-:0-162) [[174]](#cite_note-acr.org-174) Bilateral multilobar [ground-glass opacities](/wiki/Ground-glass_opacity) with a peripheral, asymmetric, distribution [crazy alveolar filling), and [consolidation](/wiki/Pulmonary_consolidation) may appear as the disease progresses. [[162]](#cite_note-:0-162) [[176]](#cite_note-176) Characteristic imaging features on chest [radiographs](/wiki/Radiographs) and [computed tomography](/wiki/Computed_tomography) (CT) of people who ground-glass opacities without [pleural effusions](/wiki/Pleural_effusion). [[177]](#cite_note-AJR-177) Many groups have created [COVID19 datasets](/wiki/COVID%E2%80%9119_datasets) that include imagery such as the [Italian Radiological Society](/wiki/Italian_Society_of_Medical_and_Interventional_Radiology) which has compiled an international online database of imaging findings for confirmed cases. [[178]](#cite_note-Cx70C-178) Due to overlap with other infections such as [adenovirus](/wiki/Adenovirus), imaging without confirmation by rRT-PCR is of limited [specificity](/wiki/Specificity_(statistics)) in identifying COVID19. [[177]](#cite_note-AJR-177) A large study in China compared chest CT results to PCR and demonstrated that though imaging is less specific for the infection, it is faster and more [sensitive](/wiki/Sensitivity_(statistics)). [[161]](#cite_note-jTxKm-161) Coding In late 2019, the WHO assigned emergency [ICD-10](/wiki/ICD-10) disease codes U07.1 for deaths from lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and U07.2 for deaths from clinically or epidemiologically diagnosed COVID19 without lab-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection. [[179]](#cite_note-ICD10_2019_U07p2-179) [white pulp](/wiki/White_pulp)depletion. [[183]](#cite_note-SatturwarFowkes2021-183) Prevention Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include getting vaccinated, staying at home, wearing a mask in public, avoiding crowded places, keeping distance from others, ventilating indoor spaces, managing potential exposure durations, [[185]](#cite_note-185) washing hands with soap and water often and for at least twenty seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands. [[186]](#cite_note-CDC042020-186) [[187]](#cite_note-187) Those diagnosed with COVID19 or who believe they may be infected are advised by the CDC to stay home except to get medical care, call ahead before visiting a healthcare provider, [wear a face mask](#Face_masks_and_respiratory_hygiene) before entering the healthcare provider's office and when in any room or vehicle with another person, cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue, regularly wash hands with soap and water and avoid sharing personal household items. [[188]](#cite_note-CDC2020IfSick-188) [[189]](#cite_note-189) The first [COVID19 vaccine](/wiki/COVID%E2%80%9119_vaccine) was granted regulatory approval on 2 December 2020 by the UK medicines regulator [MHRA](/wiki/Medicines_and_Healthcare_products_Regulatory_Agency). [[190]](#cite_note-ukgov12-2-190) It was evaluated for [emergency use authorisation](/wiki/Emergency_use_authorisation) (EUA) status by the US [FDA](/wiki/Food_and_Drugs_Administration), and in several other countries. [[191]](#cite_note-mueller-191) Initially, the US [National Institutes of Health](/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health) guidelines do not recommend any medication for prevention of COVID19, before or after exposure to the SARS-CoV-2 virus, outside the setting of a clinical trial. [[192]](#cite_note-NIHGuidelines2020-192) [[68]](#cite_note-Sanders202022-68) Without a vaccine, other prophylactic measures, or effective treatments, a key part of managing COVID19 is trying to decrease and delay the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the [curve](/wiki/Epidemic_curve)". [[193]](#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-193) This is done by slowing the infection rate to decrease the risk of health services being overwhelmed, allowing for better treatment of active cases, and delaying additional cases until effective treatments or a vaccine become available. [[193]](#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-193) [[194]](#cite_note-Wiles-194) Vaccine This article may require Prior to the [COVID19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID%E2%80%9119_pandemic), an established body of knowledge existed about the structure and function of [coronaviruses](/wiki/Coronavirus) causing diseases like severe acute respiratory syndrome ( [SARS](/wiki/SARS)) and Middle East respiratory syndrome ( [MERS](/wiki/MERS)). This knowledge accelerated the development of various [vaccine platforms](/wiki/Vaccine_platform) during early 2020. [[195]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_pmid33341119-195) The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic, often severe illness. [[196]](#cite_note-196) In 2020, the first COVID19 vaccines were developed and made available to the public through emergency authorizations [[197]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_:0-197) and conditional approvals. [[198]](#cite_note-198) [[199]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_EU_PR_20201221-199) Initially, most COVID19 vaccines were two-dose vaccines, with the sole exception being the single-dose [Janssen COVID-19 vaccine](/wiki/Janssen_COVID-19_vaccine). [[197]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_:0-197) However, immunity from the vaccines has been found to wane over time, requiring people to get [booster doses](/wiki/Booster_dose) of the vaccine to maintain protection against COVID19. [[197]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_:0-197) The COVID19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the spread of COVID19 and reducing the severity and death caused by COVID19. [[197]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_:0-197) [[200]](#cite_note-200) According to a June 2022 study, COVID19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from 8 December 2020 to 8 December 2021. [[201]](#cite_note-201) [[202]](#cite_note-202) Many countries implemented phased distribution plans that prioritized those at highest risk of complications, such as the elderly, and those at high risk of exposure and transmission, such as healthcare workers. [[203]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_Beaumont-203) [[204]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_Wang1-204) Common side effects of COVID19 vaccines include soreness, redness, rash, inflammation at the injection site, fatigue, headache, [myalgia](/wiki/Myalgia) (muscle pain), and [arthralgia](/wiki/Arthralgia) (joint pain), which resolve without medical treatment within a few days. [[205]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_who-back-205) [[206]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_:1-206) COVID-19 vaccination is safe for people who are breastfeeding. [[207]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_breastf-207) As of 18 June 2023 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19&action=edit), 13.42 billion doses of COVID19 vaccines have been administered worldwide based on official reports from [national public health agencies](/wiki/List_of_national_public_health_agencies). [[208]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_Richie_2021-208) By December 2020, more than 10 billion vaccine doses had been preordered by countries, [[209]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_mullard-209) with about half of the doses purchased by [high-income countries](/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy) comprising 14% of vaccines](/wiki/Viral_vector_vaccine), worldwide [vaccine equity](/wiki/Vaccine_equity)has development and use of [whole inactivated virus](/wiki/Whole_inactivated_virus)(WIV) and protein-based vaccines have also been recommended, especially for use in [developing countries](/wiki/Developing_countries). [[211]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_Hotez-211) [[212]](#cite_note-COVID-19_vaccine_Ye-212)The United States [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration)(FDA) has now authorized bivalent vaccines to protect against the original COVID-19 strain and its [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant). [[213]](#cite_note-213) Face masks and respiratory hygiene In community and healthcare settings, the use of face masks is intended as [source control](/wiki/Source_control_(respiratory_disease)) to limit [transmission](/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19) of the virus and for personal protection to prevent infection. [[214]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_AR2021-214) Properly worn masks both limit the [respiratory droplets](/wiki/Respiratory_droplet) and [aerosols](/wiki/Airborne_transmission) spread by infected individuals and help protect healthy individuals from infection. [[215]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Matuschek-215) [[216]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_interplay-216) Reviews of various kinds of scientific studies have concluded that masking is effective in protecting the individual against COVID-19. [[215]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Matuschek-215) [[217]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Talic-217) [[218]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_cdc-sci-218) Various [case-control](/wiki/Case%E2%80%93control_study) and population-based studies have also shown that increased levels of masking in a community reduces the spread of SARS-CoV-2, [[217]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Talic-217) [[218]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_cdc-sci-218) though there is a [randomized controlled trials](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial) (RCTs). [[219]](#cite_note-cochrane-219) [[220]](#cite_note-royalsoc-220) Masks vary in how well they work, with [N95](/wiki/N95_respirator) and surgical masks outperforming cloth masks, [[221]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Ju-221) but even cloth masks, with their variability in fabric type and mask fit, provide wearers with substantial protection from particles carrying COVID-19. [[222]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Ataei-222) [[222]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Ataei-222)and filtration effectiveness generally improves with thread count. [[221]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Ju-221)Healthcare workers, given their exposure, are recommended against using cloth masks. [[222]](#cite_note-Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_Ataei-222) Indoor ventilation and avoiding crowded indoor spaces The CDC states that avoiding crowded indoor spaces reduces the risk of COVID-19 infection. [[223]](#cite_note-:1023-223) When indoors, increasing the rate of air change, decreasing recirculation of air and increasing the use of outdoor air can reduce transmission. [[223]](#cite_note-:1023-223) [[224]](#cite_note-ecdc_transmission2-224) The WHO recommends [ventilation](/wiki/Ventilation_(architecture)) and [air filtration](/wiki/Air_filtration) in public spaces to help clear out infectious aerosols. [[225]](#cite_note-CDCasof07092020-225) [[226]](#cite_note-KoFZO-226) [[227]](#cite_note-Lancetdroplet05272020-227) Exhaled respiratory particles can build-up within enclosed spaces with inadequate [ventilation](/wiki/Ventilation_(architecture)). The risk of COVID19 infection increases especially in spaces where people engage in physical exertion or raise their voice (e.g., exercising, shouting, singing) as this increases exhalation of respiratory droplets. Prolonged exposure to these conditions, typically more than 15 minutes, leads to higher risk of infection. [[223]](#cite_note-:1023-223) [Displacement ventilation](/wiki/Displacement_ventilation) with large natural inlets can move stale air directly to the exhaust in [laminar flow](/wiki/Laminar_flow) while significantly reducing the concentration of droplets and particles. [Passive ventilation](/wiki/Passive_ventilation) reduces energy consumption and maintenance costs but may lack [controllability](/wiki/Demand_controlled_ventilation) and [heat recovery](/wiki/Heat_recovery_ventilation). Displacement ventilation can also be achieved mechanically with higher energy and maintenance costs. The use of large ducts and openings helps to prevent mixing in closed environments. Recirculation and mixing should be avoided because recirculation prevents dilution of harmful particles and redistributes possibly contaminated air, and mixing increases the concentration and range of infectious particles and keeps larger particles in the air. [[228]](#cite_note-228) Hand-washing and hygiene Thorough hand hygiene after any cough or sneeze is required. [[229]](#cite_note-:12-229) The WHO also recommends that individuals wash hands often with soap and water for at least twenty seconds, especially after going to the toilet or when hands are visibly dirty, before eating and after blowing one's nose. [[230]](#cite_note-:14-230) When soap and water are not available, the CDC recommends using an alcohol-based [hand sanitiser](/wiki/Hand_sanitiser) with at least 60% alcohol. [[231]](#cite_note-231) For areas where commercial hand sanitisers are not readily available, the WHO provides two formulations for local production. In these formulations, the antimicrobial activity arises from [ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol) or [isopropanol](/wiki/Isopropanol). [Hydrogen peroxide](/wiki/Hydrogen_peroxide) is used to help eliminate [bacterial spores](/wiki/Bacterial_spores) in the alcohol; it is "not an active substance for hand [antisepsis](/wiki/Antisepsis)." [Glycerol](/wiki/Glycerol) is added as a [humectant](/wiki/Humectant). [[232]](#cite_note-232) Social distancing Social distancing (also known as physical distancing) includes [infection control](/wiki/Infection_control) actions intended to slow the spread of the disease by minimising close contact between individuals. Methods include quarantines; travel restrictions; and the closing of schools, workplaces, stadiums, theatres, or shopping centres. Individuals may apply social distancing methods by staying at home, limiting travel, avoiding crowded areas, using no-contact greetings, and physically distancing themselves from others. [[233]](#cite_note-233) In 2020, outbreaks occurred in prisons due to crowding and an inability to enforce adequate social distancing. [[234]](#cite_note-Hawks2020-234) [[235]](#cite_note-235) In the United States, the prisoner population is ageing and many of them are at high risk for poor outcomes from COVID19 due to high rates of coexisting heart and lung disease, and poor access to high-quality healthcare. [[234]](#cite_note-Hawks2020-234) Surface cleaning After being expelled from the body, coronaviruses can survive on surfaces for hours to days. If a person touches the dirty surface, they may deposit the virus at the eyes, nose, or mouth where it can enter the body and cause infection. [[236]](#cite_note-CDCTrans-236) Evidence indicates that contact with infected surfaces is not the main driver of COVID19, [[237]](#cite_note-237) [[238]](#cite_note-238) [[239]](#cite_note-cdc.gov-239) leading to recommendations for optimised disinfection procedures to avoid issues such as the increase of [antimicrobial resistance](/wiki/Antimicrobial_resistance) through the use of inappropriate cleaning products and processes. [[240]](#cite_note-disinfection-foodindus-240) [[241]](#cite_note-241) [Deep cleaning](/wiki/Deep_clean_(COVID-19)) and other surface sanitation has been criticised as [hygiene theatre](/wiki/Hygiene_theater), giving a false sense of security against something primarily spread through the air. [[242]](#cite_note-242) [[243]](#cite_note-243) The amount of time that the virus can survive depends significantly on the type of surface, the temperature, and the humidity. [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) Coronaviruses die very quickly when exposed to the [UV light](/wiki/UV_light) in [sunlight](/wiki/Sunlight). [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) Like other enveloped viruses, SARS-CoV-2 survives longest when the temperature is at [room temperature](/wiki/Room_temperature) or lower, and when the [relative humidity](/wiki/Relative_humidity) is low (<50%). [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) On many surfaces, including glass, some types of plastic, stainless steel, and skin, the virus can remain infective for several days indoors at room temperature, or even about a week under ideal conditions. [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) [[245]](#cite_note-245) On some surfaces, including cotton fabric and copper, the virus usually dies after a few hours. [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) The virus dies faster on porous surfaces than on non-porous surfaces due to capillary action within pores and faster aerosol droplet evaporation. [[246]](#cite_note-246) [[239]](#cite_note-cdc.gov-239) [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) However, of the many surfaces tested, two with the longest survival times are N95 respirator masks and surgical masks, both of which are considered porous surfaces. [[244]](#cite_note-:4-244) The CDC says that in most situations, cleaning surfaces with soap or detergent, not disinfecting, is enough to reduce risk of transmission. [[247]](#cite_note-:16-247) [[248]](#cite_note-248) The CDC recommends that if a COVID19 case is suspected or confirmed at a facility such as an office or day care, all areas such as offices, bathrooms, common areas, shared electronic equipment like tablets, touch screens, keyboards, remote controls, and ATMs used by the ill persons should be disinfected. [[249]](#cite_note-sxygw-249) Surfaces may be decontaminated with 62-71 per cent [ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol), 50-100 per cent isopropanol, 0.1 per cent [sodium hypochlorite](/wiki/Sodium_hypochlorite), 0.5 per cent hydrogen 0.2-7.5 per cent [povidone-iodine](/wiki/Povidone-iodine), or 50-200 ppm are less effective. [Ultraviolet germicidal irradiation](/wiki/Ultraviolet_germicidal_irradiation) may also be used, [[225]](#cite_note-CDCasof07092020-225) although popular devices require 5-10 min exposure and may deteriorate some materials over time. [[250]](#cite_note-250) A datasheet comprising the authorised substances to disinfection in the food industry (including suspension or surface tested, kind of surface, use dilution, disinfectant and inoculum volumes) can be seen in the supplementary material of. [[240]](#cite_note-disinfection-foodindus-240) Self-isolation [Self-isolation](/wiki/Self-isolation) at home has been recommended for those diagnosed with COVID19 and those who suspect they have been infected. Health agencies have issued detailed instructions for proper self-isolation. [[251]](#cite_note-pmid33012884-251) Many governments have mandated or recommended self-quarantine for entire populations. The strongest self-quarantine instructions have been issued to those in high-risk groups. [[252]](#cite_note-lZR3i-252) Those who may have been exposed to someone with COVID19 and those who have recently travelled to a country or region with the widespread transmission have been advised to self-quarantine for 14 days from the time of last possible exposure. [[253]](#cite_note-253) A 2021 Cochrane rapid review found that based upon low-certainty evidence, international travel-related control measures such as restricting cross-border travel may help to contain the spread of COVID19. [[254]](#cite_note-:2-254) Additionally, symptom/exposure-based screening measures at borders may miss many positive cases. [[254]](#cite_note-:2-254) While test-based border screening measures may be more effective, it could also miss many positive cases if only conducted upon arrival without follow-up. The review concluded that a minimum 10-day quarantine may be beneficial in preventing the spread of COVID19 and may be more effective if combined with an additional control measure like border screening. [[254]](#cite_note-:2-254) Treatment Although several medications have been approved in different countries as of April 2022, not all countries have these medications. Patients with mild to moderate symptoms who are in the risk groups can take [nirmatrelvir/ritonavir](/wiki/Nirmatrelvir/ritonavir) (marketed as Paxlovid) or [remdesivir](/wiki/Remdesivir), either of which reduces the risk of serious illness or hospitalization. [[255]](#cite_note-255) In the US, the [Biden Administration COVID-19 action plan](/wiki/Biden_Administration_COVID-19_action_plan) includes the Test to Treat initiative, where people can go to a pharmacy, take a COVID test, and immediately receive free Paxlovid if they test positive. [[256]](#cite_note-256) Highly effective vaccines have reduced mortality related to SARS-CoV-2; however, for those awaiting vaccination, as well as for the estimated millions of immunocompromised persons who are unlikely to respond robustly to vaccination, treatment remains important. [[257]](#cite_note-257) The cornerstone of [management of COVID-19](/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19) has been and [prone positioning](/wiki/Prone_positioning) as needed, and medications or devices to support other affected vital organs. [[258]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_NatureDale_Fisher_&_David_Heymann-258) [[259]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_KuiFang2020-259) [[260]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_Wang_Du_Zhu_Cao_2020_p.-260) Most cases of COVID-19 are mild. In these, supportive care includes medication such as [paracetamol](/wiki/Paracetamol) or [NSAIDs](/wiki/NSAID) to relieve symptoms (fever, body aches, cough), proper intake of fluids, rest, and [nasal breathing](/wiki/Obligate_nasal_breathing). [[261]](#cite_note-261) [[262]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_AutoDW-63-262) [[263]](#cite_note-263) [[264]](#cite_note-264) Good [healthy diet](/wiki/Healthy_diet) are also recommended. [[265]](#cite_note-265) As of April 2020 the U.S. [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) recommended that those who suspect they are carrying the virus isolate themselves at home and wear a face mask. [[266]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_CDC2020IfSick-266) [glucocorticoid](/wiki/Glucocorticoid) [dexamethasone](/wiki/Dexamethasone)had been strongly recommended in those severe cases treated in hospital with low oxygen levels, to reduce the risk of death. [[267]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_:3-267) [[268]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_:0-268) [[269]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_:1-269) [Noninvasive be required to support breathing. [[270]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_NIHGuidelines2020-270) [Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation)(ECMO) has been used to address respiratory failure, but its benefits are still under consideration. [[271]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p.-271) [[272]](#cite_note-Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19_Henry_2020_p.-272)Some of the cases of severe disease course are caused by systemic hyper-inflammation, the so-called cytokine storm. [[273]](#cite_note-273) Prognosis and risk factors The severity of COVID19 varies. The disease may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold). In 3-4% of cases (7.4% for those over age 65) symptoms are severe enough to cause hospitalisation. [[274]](#cite_note-pmid33087398-274) Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover. Among those who have died, the time from symptom onset to death has ranged from two to eight weeks. [[99]](#cite_note-WHOReport24Feb2020-99) The Italian [Istituto Superiore di Sanità](/wiki/Istituto_Superiore_di_Sanit%C3%A0) reported that the median time between the onset of symptoms and death was twelve days, with seven being hospitalised. However, people transferred to an ICU had a median time of ten days between hospitalisation and death. [[275]](#cite_note-ISSCharacteristics-275) Abnormal sodium levels during hospitalisation with COVID-19 are associated with poor prognoses: high sodium with a greater risk of death, and low sodium with an increased chance of needing ventilator support. [[276]](#cite_note-276) [[277]](#cite_note-277) Prolonged [prothrombin](/wiki/Prothrombin) time and elevated [C-reactive protein](/wiki/C-reactive_protein) levels on admission to the hospital are associated with severe course of COVID19 and with a transfer to ICU. [[278]](#cite_note-278) [[279]](#cite_note-279) Some early studies suggest 10% to 20% of people with COVID19 will experience [symptoms lasting longer than a month](/wiki/Long_COVID). [[280]](#cite_note-NIHRreportSep20-280) [[281]](#cite_note-HvIJa-281) A majority of those who were admitted to hospital with severe disease report long-term problems including fatigue and shortness of breath. [[282]](#cite_note-UniWashingtonSep20-282) On 30 October 2020, WHO chief [Tedros Adhanom](/wiki/Tedros_Adhanom) warned that "to a significant number of people, the COVID virus poses a range of serious long-term effects." He has described the vast spectrum of COVID19 symptoms that fluctuate over time as "really concerning". They range from fatigue, a cough and shortness of breath, to inflammation and injury of major organs - including the lungs and heart, and also neurological and psychologic effects. Symptoms often overlap and can affect any system in the body. Infected people have reported cyclical bouts of fatigue, headaches, months of complete exhaustion, mood swings, and other symptoms. Tedros therefore concluded that a strategy of achieving [herd immunity](/wiki/Herd_immunity) by infection, rather than vaccination, is "morally unconscionable and unfeasible". [[283]](#cite_note-OaTsI-283) In terms of hospital readmissions about 9% of 106,000 individuals had to return for hospital treatment within two months of discharge. The average to readmit was eight days since first hospital visit. There are several risk factors that have been identified as being a cause of multiple admissions to a hospital facility. Among these are advanced age (above 65 years of age) and presence of a chronic condition such as diabetes, COPD, heart failure or chronic kidney disease. [[284]](#cite_note-rArHO-284) [[285]](#cite_note-CtbMg-285) According to [scientific reviews](/wiki/Scientific_review) smokers are more likely to require intensive care or die compared to non-smokers. [[286]](#cite_note-286) [[287]](#cite_note-engin-review-287) Acting on the same ACE2 pulmonary receptors affected by smoking, air pollution has been correlated with the disease. [[287]](#cite_note-engin-review-287) Short term [[288]](#cite_note-288) and chronic [[289]](#cite_note-289) exposure to air pollution seems to enhance morbidity and mortality from COVID19. [[290]](#cite_note-290) [[291]](#cite_note-291) [[292]](#cite_note-292) Pre-existing heart and lung diseases [[293]](#cite_note-293) and also [obesity](/wiki/Obesity), especially in conjunction with [fatty liver disease](/wiki/Fatty_liver_disease), contributes to an increased health risk of COVID19. [[287]](#cite_note-engin-review-287) [[294]](#cite_note-294) [[295]](#cite_note-295) [[296]](#cite_note-296) It is also assumed that those that are immunocompromised are at higher risk of getting severely sick from SARS-CoV-2. [[297]](#cite_note-297) One research study that looked into the COVID19 infections in hospitalised kidney transplant recipients found a mortality rate of 11%. [[298]](#cite_note-298) Men with untreated [hypogonadism](/wiki/Hypogonadism) were 2.4 times more likely than men with eugonadism to be hospitalised if they contracted COVID-19; Hypogonad men treated with [testosterone](/wiki/Testosterone) were less likely to be hospitalised for COVID-19 than men who were not treated for hypogonadism. [[299]](#cite_note-jama-299) Genetic risk factors [Genetics](/wiki/Genetics) plays an important role in the ability to fight off Covid. [[300]](#cite_note-pmid33888907-300) For instance, those that do not produce detectable [type I interferons](/wiki/Type_I_interferon) or produce [auto-antibodies](/wiki/Autoantibody) against these sicker from COVID19. [[301]](#cite_note-301) [[302]](#cite_note-302) [Genetic screening](/wiki/Genetic_screening) is interferon effector genes. [[303]](#cite_note-303) Some genetic variants are risk factors in specific populations. For instance, an [allele](/wiki/Allele) of the [DOCK2](/wiki/DOCK2) gene (dedicator of cytokinesis 2 gene) is a common risk factor in Asian populations but much less common in Europe. The mutation leads to lower expression of DOCK2 especially in younger patients with severe Covid. [[304]](#cite_note-304) In fact, many other genes and genetic variants have been found that determine the outcome of SARS-CoV-2 infections. [[305]](#cite_note-305) Children While very young children have experienced lower rates of infection, older children have a rate of infection that is similar to the population as a whole. [[306]](#cite_note-306) [[307]](#cite_note-307) Children are likely to have milder symptoms and are at lower risk of severe disease than adults. [[308]](#cite_note-Reardon-308) The CDC reports that in the US roughly a third of hospitalised children were admitted to the ICU, [[309]](#cite_note-309) while a European multinational study of hospitalised children from June 2020, found that about 8% of children admitted to a hospital needed intensive care. [[310]](#cite_note-310) Four of the 582 children (0.7%) in the European study died, but the actual mortality rate may be "substantially lower" since milder cases that did not seek medical help were not included in the study. [[311]](#cite_note-311) [[312]](#cite_note-CDC_2020children-312) Long-term effects Around 10% to 30% of non-hospitalised people with COVID-19 go on to develop [long COVID](/wiki/Long_COVID). For those that do need hospitalisation, the incidence of long-term effects is over 50%. [[14]](#cite_note-davis-14) Long COVID is an often severe multisystem disease, with a large set of symptoms. There are likely various, possibly coinciding, causes. [[14]](#cite_note-davis-14) Organ damage from the acute infection can explain a part of the symptoms, but long COVID is also observed in people where organ damage seems to be absent. [[313]](#cite_note-pmid35594336-313) By a variety of mechanisms, the lungs are the organs most affected in COVID19. [[314]](#cite_note-Torres-314) In people requiring hospital admission, up to 98% of CT scans performed show lung abnormalities after 28 days of illness even if they had clinically improved. [[315]](#cite_note-315) People with advanced age, severe disease, prolonged ICU stays, or who smoke are more likely to have long-lasting effects, including pulmonary fibrosis. [[316]](#cite_note-Rai-316) Overall, approximately one-third of those investigated after four weeks will have findings of [pulmonary fibrosis](/wiki/Pulmonary_fibrosis) or reduced lung function as measured by [DLCO](/wiki/DLCO), even in asymptomatic people, but with the suggestion of continuing improvement with the passing of more time. [[314]](#cite_note-Torres-314) After severe disease, lung function can take anywhere from three months to a year or more to return to previous levels. [[317]](#cite_note-317) The risks of [cognitive deficit](/wiki/Cognitive_deficit), [dementia](/wiki/Dementia), psychotic disorders, and [epilepsy](/wiki/Epilepsy) or seizures persists at an increased level two years after infection. [[318]](#cite_note-318) Immunity The [immune response](/wiki/Immune_response) by humans to SARS-CoV-2 virus occurs as a combination of the [cell-mediated immunity](/wiki/Cell-mediated_immunity) and antibody production, [[319]](#cite_note-319) just as with most other infections. [[320]](#cite_note-320) B cells interact with T cells and begin dividing before selection into the plasma cell, partly on the basis of their affinity for antigen. [[321]](#cite_note-321) Since SARS-CoV-2 has been in the human population only since December 2019, it remains unknown if the [immunity](/wiki/Immunity_(medical)) is long-lasting in people who recover from the disease. [[322]](#cite_note-CohenJI2020Dec-322) The presence of neutralising antibodies in blood strongly correlates with protection from infection, but the level of neutralising antibody declines with time. Those with asymptomatic or mild disease had undetectable levels of neutralising antibody two months after infection. In another study, the level of neutralising antibodies fell four-fold one to four months after the onset of symptoms. However, the lack of antibodies in the blood does not mean antibodies will not be rapidly produced upon reexposure to SARS-CoV-2. Memory B cells specific for the spike and nucleocapsid proteins of SARS-CoV-2 last for at least six months after the appearance of symptoms. [[322]](#cite_note-CohenJI2020Dec-322) As of August 2021, reinfection with COVID19 was possible but uncommon. The first case of reinfection was documented in August 2020. [[323]](#cite_note-:24-323) A systematic review found 17 cases of confirmed reinfection in medical literature as of May 2021. [[323]](#cite_note-:24-323) With the [Omicron variant](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant), as of 2022, reinfections have become common, albeit it is unclear how common. [[324]](#cite_note-abc-reinfections-324) [COVID-19 reinfections](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2#Reinfection) are thought to likely be less severe than primary infections, especially if one was previously infected by the same variant. [[324]](#cite_note-abc-reinfections-324)[ [additional citation(s) needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Mortality Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality. [[325]](#cite_note-325) These numbers vary by region and over time and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since the initial outbreak, and population characteristics such as age, sex, and overall health. [[326]](#cite_note-326) The [mortality rate](/wiki/Mortality_rate) reflects the number of deaths within a specific demographic group divided by the population of that demographic group. Consequently, the mortality rate reflects the prevalence as well as the severity of the disease within a given population. Mortality rates are highly correlated to age, with relatively low rates for young people and relatively high rates among the elderly. [[327]](#cite_note-JAMAPedsCOVID19-327) [[328]](#cite_note-Lu_Zhang_Du_Zhang_p.-328) [[329]](#cite_note-pediatrics_tong-329) In fact, one relevant factor of mortality rates is the age structure of the countries' populations. For example, the case fatality rate for COVID19 is lower in India than in the US since India's younger population represents a larger percentage than in the US. [[330]](#cite_note-:19-330) Case fatality rate The [case fatality rate](/wiki/Case_fatality_rate) (CFR) reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval. Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 1.02% (6,881,955/676,609,955) as of 10 March 2023. [[331]](#cite_note-JHU_ticker-331) The number varies by region. [[332]](#cite_note-332) [[333]](#cite_note-333) - Total confirmed cases over time - Total confirmed cases of COVID19 per million people [[334]](#cite_note-334) - Total confirmed deaths over time - Total confirmed deaths due to COVID19 per million people [[335]](#cite_note-335) Infection fatality rate A key metric in gauging the severity of COVID19 is the [infection fatality rate](/wiki/Infection_fatality_rate) (IFR), also referred to as the infection fatality ratio or infection fatality risk. [[336]](#cite_note-336) [[337]](#cite_note-337) [[338]](#cite_note-338) This metric is calculated by dividing the total number of deaths from the disease by the total number of infected individuals; hence, in contrast to the [CFR](/wiki/Case_fatality_rate), the IFR incorporates asymptomatic and undiagnosed infections as well as reported cases. [[339]](#cite_note-urlGeneralized_trapezoidal_ogive_curves_for_fatality_rate_modeling-339) Estimates A December 2020 systematic review and meta-analysis estimated that population IFR during the first wave of the pandemic was about 0.5% to 1% in many locations (including France, Netherlands, New Zealand, and Portugal), 1% to 2% in other locations (Australia, England, Lithuania, and Spain), and exceeded 2% in Italy. [[340]](#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-340) That study also found that most of these differences in IFR reflected corresponding differences in the age composition of the population and age-specific infection rates; in particular, the metaregression estimate of IFR is very low for children and younger adults (e.g., 0.002% at age 10 and 0.01% at age 25) but increases progressively to 0.4% at age 55, 1.4% at age 65, 4.6% at age 75, and 15% at age 85. [[340]](#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-340) These results were also highlighted in a December 2020 report issued by the IFR rates indicates that COVID19 is hazardous not only for the elderly but also for middle-aged adults, for whom the infection fatality rate of COVID-19 is two orders of magnitude greater than the annualised risk of a fatal automobile accident and far more dangerous than seasonal [influenza](/wiki/Influenza). [[340]](#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-340) Earlier estimates of IFR At an early stage of the pandemic, the World Health Organization reported estimates of IFR between 0.3% and 1%. [[342]](#cite_note-342) [[343]](#cite_note-343) On 2 July, The WHO's chief scientist reported that the average IFR estimate presented at a two-day WHO expert forum was about 0.6%. [[344]](#cite_note-NYT-20200704dm-344) [[345]](#cite_note-345) In August, the WHO found that studies incorporating data from broad serology testing in Europe showed IFR estimates converging at approximately 0.5-1%. [[346]](#cite_note-346) Firm lower limits of IFRs have been established in a number of locations such as New York City and Bergamo in Italy since the IFR cannot be less than the population fatality rate. (After sufficient time however, people can get reinfected). [[347]](#cite_note-347) As of 10 July, in New York City, with a population of 8.4 million, 23,377 individuals (18,758 confirmed and 4,619 probable) have died with COVID19 (0.3% of the population). [[348]](#cite_note-348) Antibody testing in New York City suggested an IFR 0.9%, [[349]](#cite_note-349) and 1.4%. [[350]](#cite_note-350) of the population has died. [[351]](#cite_note-351) In September 2020, the U.S. [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) reported preliminary estimates of age-specific IFRs for public health planning purposes.
