However, in a few countries like India, Nepal, Vietnam, and Slovenia the fatality cases are higher in women than men. [[330]](#cite_note-:19-330) Globally, men are more likely to be admitted to the [ICU](/wiki/Intensive_care_unit) and more likely to die. [[354]](#cite_note-354) [[355]](#cite_note-355) One meta-analysis found that globally, men were more likely to get COVID19 than women; there were approximately 55 men and 45 women per 100 infections ( [CI](/wiki/Confidence_interval): 51.43-56.58). [[356]](#cite_note-356) The [Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Chinese_Center_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) reported the death rate was 2.8% for men and 1.7% for women. [[357]](#cite_note-Epidemiology17Feb2020-357) Later reviews in June 2020 indicated that there is no significant difference in susceptibility or in CFR between genders. [[358]](#cite_note-358) [[359]](#cite_note-359) One review acknowledges the different mortality rates in Chinese men, suggesting that it may be attributable to lifestyle choices such as smoking and drinking alcohol rather than genetic factors. [[360]](#cite_note-360) Smoking, which in some countries like China is mainly a male activity, is a habit that contributes to increasing significantly the case fatality rates among men. [[330]](#cite_note-:19-330) Sex-based immunological differences, lesser prevalence of smoking in women and men developing co-morbid conditions such as hypertension at a younger age than women could have contributed to the higher mortality in men. [[361]](#cite_note-nyt-italy-361) In Europe as of February 2020, 57% of the infected people were men and 72% of those died with COVID19 were men. [[362]](#cite_note-362) As of April 2020, the US government is not tracking sex-related data of COVID19 infections. [[363]](#cite_note-nytimesus-363) Research has shown that viral illnesses like Ebola, HIV, influenza and SARS affect men and women differently. [[363]](#cite_note-nytimesus-363) Ethnic differences In the US, a greater proportion of deaths due to COVID19 have occurred among African Americans and other minority groups. [[364]](#cite_note-AVD-364) Structural factors that prevent them from practising social distancing include their concentration in crowded substandard housing and in "essential" occupations such as retail grocery workers, public transit employees, health-care workers and custodial staff. Greater prevalence of lacking [health insurance](/wiki/Health_insurance) and care of underlying conditions such as [diabetes](/wiki/Diabetes), [[365]](#cite_note-:25-365) hypertension, and [heart disease](/wiki/Heart_disease) also increase their risk of death. [[366]](#cite_note-366) Similar issues affect [Native American](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas) and [Latino](/wiki/Latino_(demonym)) communities. [[364]](#cite_note-AVD-364) On the one hand, in the Dominican Republic there is a clear example of both gender and ethnic inequality. In this Latin American territory, there is great inequality and precariousness that especially affects Dominican women, with greater emphasis on those of Haitian descent. [[367]](#cite_note-:18-367) According to a US health policy non-profit, 34% of American Indian and Alaska Native People (AIAN) non-elderly adults are at risk of serious illness compared to 21% of white non-elderly adults. [[368]](#cite_note-368) The source attributes it to disproportionately high rates of many health conditions that may put them at higher risk as well as living conditions like lack of access to clean water. [[369]](#cite_note-369) Leaders have called for efforts to research and address the disparities. [[370]](#cite_note-370) In the UK, a greater proportion of deaths due to COVID19 have occurred in those of a [Black](/wiki/Black_British_people), [Asian](/wiki/British_Asian), and other ethnic minority background. [[371]](#cite_note-371) [[372]](#cite_note-372) [[373]](#cite_note-373) More severe impacts upon patients including the relative incidence of the necessity of hospitalisation requirements, and vulnerability to the disease has been associated via DNA analysis to be expressed in genetic variants at chromosomal region 3, features that are associated with European [Neanderthal](/wiki/Neanderthal) heritage. That structure imposes greater risks that those affected will develop a more severe form of the disease. [[374]](#cite_note-Neanderthal-374) The findings are from Professor Svante Pääbo and researchers he leads at the [Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology](/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_for_Evolutionary_Anthropology) and the [Karolinska Institutet](/wiki/Karolinska_Institutet). [[374]](#cite_note-Neanderthal-374) This admixture of modern human and Neanderthal genes is estimated to have occurred roughly between 50,000 and 60,000 years ago in Southern Europe. [[374]](#cite_note-Neanderthal-374) Comorbidities [Biological](/wiki/Biology) factors (immune response) and the general behaviour (habits) can strongly determine the consequences of COVID19. [[330]](#cite_note-:19-330) Most of those who die of COVID19 have [cardiovascular disease](/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease). [[375]](#cite_note-:8-375) According to March data from the United States, 89% of those hospitalised had preexisting conditions. [[376]](#cite_note-376) The Italian Istituto Superiore di Sanità reported that out of 8.8% of deaths where [medical charts](/wiki/Medical_record) were available, 96.1% of people had at least one [comorbidity](/wiki/Comorbidity) with the average person having 3.4 diseases. [[275]](#cite_note-ISSCharacteristics-275) According to this report the most common comorbidities are hypertension (66% of deaths), [type 2 diabetes](/wiki/Type_2_diabetes) and renal failure](/wiki/Chronic_renal_failure) (20.2% of deaths). Most critical respiratory comorbidities according to the US [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC), are: [[377]](#cite_note-377) Evidence stemming from [meta-analysis](/wiki/Meta-analysis) of several smaller research papers also suggests that smoking can be associated with worse outcomes. [[378]](#cite_note-378) [[379]](#cite_note-379) When someone with existing respiratory problems is infected with COVID19, they might be at greater risk for severe symptoms. [[380]](#cite_note-380) COVID19 also poses a greater risk to people who [misuse opioids](/wiki/Opioid_use_disorder) and [amphetamines](/wiki/Stimulant_use_disorder), insofar as their drug use may have caused lung damage. [[381]](#cite_note-381) In August 2020, the CDC issued a caution that [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis) (TB) infections could increase the risk of severe illness or death. The WHO recommended that people with respiratory symptoms be screened for both diseases, as testing positive for COVID19 could not rule out co-infections. Some projections have estimated that reduced TB detection due to the pandemic could result in 6.3 million additional TB cases and 1.4 million TB-related deaths by 2025. [[382]](#cite_note-382) History This section needs to be updated. The reason given is: excessive detail about the very early pandemic while missing an overview of the later pandemic.(July 2023) |Part of |[COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic) [COVID-19](disease) [SARS-CoV-2](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2)(virus) [COVID-19 portal](/wiki/Portal:COVID-19) The virus is thought to be of natural animal origin, most likely through [spillover infection](/wiki/Spillover_infection). [[94]](#cite_note-NM-20200317-94) [[383]](#cite_note-PMC7969828-383) [[384]](#cite_note-384) A joint-study conducted in early by the People's Republic of China and the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) indicated that the virus descended from a coronavirus that infects wild bats, and likely spread to humans through an intermediary wildlife host. [[385]](#cite_note-385) There are several theories about where the [index case](/wiki/Index_case) originated and [investigations into the origin of the pandemic](/wiki/Investigations_into_the_origin_of_COVID-19) are ongoing. [[386]](#cite_note-patientZero-386) According to articles published in July 2022 in [Science](/wiki/Science_(journal)), virus transmission into humans occurred through two spillover events in November 2019 and was likely due to live wildlife trade on the [Huanan wet market](/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Wholesale_Market) in the city of [Wuhan](/wiki/Wuhan) (Hubei, China). [[387]](#cite_note-387) [[388]](#cite_note-388) [[389]](#cite_note-389) Doubts about the conclusions have mostly centered on the precise site of spillover. [[390]](#cite_note-390) Earlier [phylogenetics](/wiki/Phylogenetics) estimated that SARS-CoV-2 arose in October or November 2019. [[391]](#cite_note-evolutionary-391) [[392]](#cite_note-zoonotic-392) [[393]](#cite_note-dorp_evo-393) A phylogenetic algorithm analysis suggested that the virus may have been circulating in [Guangdong](/wiki/Guangdong) before Wuhan. [[394]](#cite_note-394) Most scientists believe the virus spilled into human populations through natural [zoonosis](/wiki/Zoonosis), similar to the [SARS-CoV-1](/wiki/SARS-CoV-1) and [MERS-CoV](/wiki/MERS-CoV) outbreaks, and consistent with other pandemics in human history. [[395]](#cite_note-pekar-395) [[396]](#cite_note-jiang_wang-396) According to the [Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change](/wiki/Intergovernmental_Panel_on_Climate_Change) several social and environmental factors including [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change), [natural ecosystem destruction](/wiki/Environmental_degradation) and such [zoonotic spillover](/wiki/Zoonosis). [[397]](#cite_note-397) [[398]](#cite_note-398) One study made with the support of the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union) found [climate change](/wiki/Climate_change) increased the likelihood of the pandemic by influencing distribution of bat species. [[399]](#cite_note-399) [[400]](#cite_note-400) Available evidence suggests that the SARS-CoV-2 virus was originally harboured by bats, and spread to humans multiple times from infected wild animals at the [Huanan Seafood Market](/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Market) in [Wuhan](/wiki/Wuhan) in December 2019. [[395]](#cite_note-pekar-395) [[396]](#cite_note-jiang_wang-396) A minority of scientists and some members of the [U.S intelligence community](/wiki/United_States_Intelligence_Community) believe the virus may have been [unintentionally leaked](/wiki/COVID-19_lab_leak_theory) from a laboratory such as the [Wuhan Institute of Virology](/wiki/Wuhan_Institute_of_Virology). [[401]](#cite_note-NYT_DoE_Feb2023-401) [[402]](#cite_note-Hill_Feb_2023_DoE-402) The US intelligence community has mixed views on the issue, [[403]](#cite_note-CNN_Feb2023_LeBlanc-403) [[404]](#cite_note-Guardian_Feb2023-404) but overall agrees with the scientific consensus that the virus was not developed as a [biological weapon](/wiki/Biological_agent) and is unlikely to have been [genetically [[406]](#cite_note-406) [[407]](#cite_note-407) [[408]](#cite_note-408) There is no evidence SARS-CoV-2 existed in any laboratory prior to the pandemic. [[409]](#cite_note-critical-409) [[410]](#cite_note-Gorski-410) [[411]](#cite_note-HolmesConversationDead-411) The first confirmed human infections were in Wuhan. A study of the first 41 cases of confirmed COVID19, published in January 2020 in The Lancet, reported the earliest date of onset of symptoms as 1 December 2019. [[412]](#cite_note-WuMarch2020-412) [[413]](#cite_note-Wang24Jan2020-413) [[414]](#cite_note-AutoDW-67-414) Official publications from the WHO reported the earliest onset of symptoms as 8 December 2019. [[415]](#cite_note-415) Human-to-human transmission was confirmed by the WHO and Chinese authorities by 20 January 2020. [[416]](#cite_note-416) [[417]](#cite_note-417) According to official Chinese sources, these were mostly linked to the [Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market](/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Wholesale_Market), which also sold live animals. [[418]](#cite_note-characteristicsZH-418) In May 2020, [George Gao](/wiki/George_F._Gao), the director of the CDC, said animal samples collected from the seafood market had tested negative for the virus, indicating that the market was the site of an early [superspreading event](/wiki/Superspreader), but that it was not the site of the initial outbreak. [[419]](#cite_note-419) Traces of the virus have been found in wastewater samples that were collected in [Milan](/wiki/Milan) and [Turin](/wiki/Turin), Italy, on 18 December 2019. [[420]](#cite_note-420) By December 2019, the spread of infection was almost entirely driven by human-to-human transmission. [[357]](#cite_note-Epidemiology17Feb2020-357) [[421]](#cite_note-421) The number of COVID-19 cases in Hubei gradually increased, reaching sixty by 20 December, [[422]](#cite_note-422) and at least 266 by 31 December. [[423]](#cite_note-423) On 24 December, [Wuhan Central Hospital](/wiki/Wuhan_Central_Hospital) sent a [bronchoalveolar lavage fluid](/wiki/Bronchoalveolar_lavage_fluid) (BAL) sample from an unresolved clinical case to sequencing company Vision Medicals. On 27 and 28 December, Vision Medicals informed the Wuhan Central Hospital and the Chinese CDC of the results of the test, showing a new coronavirus. [[424]](#cite_note-424) A pneumonia cluster of unknown cause was observed on 26 December and treated by the doctor [Zhang Jixian](/wiki/Zhang_Jixian) in Hubei Provincial Hospital, who informed the Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December. [[425]](#cite_note-425) On 30 December, a test report addressed to Wuhan Central Hospital, from company CapitalBio Medlab, stated an erroneous positive result for [SARS](/wiki/SARS), causing a group of doctors at Wuhan Central Hospital to alert their colleagues and relevant hospital authorities of the result. The Wuhan Municipal Health Commission issued a notice to various medical institutions on "the treatment of pneumonia of unknown cause" that same evening. [[426]](#cite_note-426) Eight of these doctors, including [Li Wenliang](/wiki/Li_Wenliang) (punished on 3 January), [[427]](#cite_note-427) were later admonished by the police for spreading false rumours and another, [Ai Fen](/wiki/Ai_Fen), was reprimanded by her superiors for raising the alarm. [[428]](#cite_note-428) The Wuhan Municipal Health Commission made the first public announcement of a pneumonia outbreak of unknown cause on 31 December, confirming 27 cases [[429]](#cite_note-AutoDW-69-429) [[430]](#cite_note-430) [[431]](#cite_note-AutoDW-68-431) - enough to trigger an investigation. [[432]](#cite_note-bbc50984025-432) During the early stages of the outbreak, the number of cases doubled approximately every seven and a half days. [[433]](#cite_note-Qun29Jan2020-433) In early and mid-January 2020, the virus spread to other [Chinese provinces](/wiki/Provinces_of_China), helped by the [Chinese New Year migration](/wiki/Chunyun) and Wuhan being a transport hub and major rail interchange. [[99]](#cite_note-WHOReport24Feb2020-99) On 20 January, China reported nearly 140 new cases in one day, including two people in Beijing and one in [Shenzhen](/wiki/Shenzhen). [[434]](#cite_note-france2420200120-434) Later official data shows 6,174 people had already developed symptoms by then, [[357]](#cite_note-Epidemiology17Feb2020-357) and more may have been infected. [[435]](#cite_note-flattery-435) A report in The Lancet on 24 January indicated human transmission, strongly recommended personal protective equipment for health workers, and said testing for the virus was essential due to its "pandemic potential". [[133]](#cite_note-Huang24Jan2020-133) [[436]](#cite_note-Horton_18_March-436) On 30 January, the WHO declared COVID-19 a [Public Health Emergency of International Concern](/wiki/Public_Health_Emergency_of_International_Concern). [[435]](#cite_note-flattery-435) By this time, the outbreak spread by a factor of 100 to 200 times. [[437]](#cite_note-437) Italy had its first confirmed cases on 31 January 2020, two tourists from China. [[438]](#cite_note-Corriere_20Jan-438) Italy overtook China as the country with the most deaths on 19 March 2020. [[439]](#cite_note-sky11960412-439) By 26 March the United States had overtaken China and Italy with the highest number of confirmed cases in the world. [[440]](#cite_note-NYT-20200326-440) Research on coronavirus genomes indicates the majority of COVID-19 cases in [New York](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_York_(state)) came from European travellers, rather than directly from China or any other Asian country. [[441]](#cite_note-20200408nytimes-441) Retesting of prior samples found a person in France who had the virus on 27 December 2019, [[442]](#cite_note-France-retest-442) [[443]](#cite_note-:22-443) and a person in the United States who died from the disease on 6 February 2020. [[444]](#cite_note-PBS-2wks-444) RT-PCR testing of untreated wastewater samples from Brazil and Italy have suggested detection of SARS-CoV-2 as early as November and December 2019, respectively, but the methods of such sewage studies have not been optimised, many have not been peer-reviewed, details are often missing, and there is a risk of false positives due to contamination or if only one gene target is detected. [[445]](#cite_note-445) A September 2020 review journal article said, "The possibility that the COVID19 infection had already spread to Europe at the end of last year is now indicated by abundant, even if partially circumstantial, evidence", including pneumonia case numbers and radiology in France and Italy in November and December. [[446]](#cite_note-platto-446) As of 1 October 2021 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19&action=edit), [Reuters](/wiki/Reuters) reported that it had estimated the worldwide total number of deaths due to COVID19 to have exceeded five million. [[447]](#cite_note-447) The Public Health Emergency of International Concern for COVID-19 ended on May 5, 2023. By this time, everyday life in most countries had returned to how it was before the pandemic. [[448]](#cite_note-448) [[449]](#cite_note-449) Misinformation After the initial outbreak of COVID19, [misinformation](/wiki/Misinformation) and [disinformation](/wiki/Disinformation) regarding the origin, scale, prevention, treatment, and other aspects of the disease rapidly spread online. [[450]](#cite_note-bbc_misinfo-450) [[451]](#cite_note-GUAR-451) [[452]](#cite_note-RunningList-452) In September 2020, the US [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) published preliminary estimates of the risk of death by age groups in the United States, but those estimates were widely misreported and misunderstood. [[453]](#cite_note-453) [[454]](#cite_note-454) Other species Humans appear to be capable of spreading the virus to some other animals, [[455]](#cite_note-Gryseels_2021_MammalReview-455) [[456]](#cite_note-TanLam2022_NatComm-456) a type of disease transmission referred to as [zooanthroponosis](/wiki/Anthroponotic_disease). [[457]](#cite_note-Pappas_MDPI_2022-457) [[458]](#cite_note-MunirAshraf_2020-458) Some pets, especially cats and [ferrets](/wiki/Ferret), can catch this virus from infected humans. [[459]](#cite_note-:7-459) [[460]](#cite_note-460) Symptoms in cats include [respiratory](/wiki/Respiratory_symptom) (such as a cough) and digestive symptoms. [[459]](#cite_note-:7-459) Cats can spread the virus to other cats, and may be able to spread the virus to humans, but cat-to-human transmission of SARS-CoV-2 has not been proven. [[459]](#cite_note-:7-459) [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) Compared to cats, dogs are less susceptible to this infection. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) Behaviours which increase the risk of transmission include kissing, licking, and petting the animal. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) The virus does not appear to be able to infect [pigs](/wiki/Domestic_pig), [ducks](/wiki/Domestic_duck), or chickens at all. [[459]](#cite_note-:7-459) [Mice](/wiki/Mouse), rats, and rabbits, if they can be infected at all, are unlikely to be involved in spreading the virus. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) Tigers and lions in zoos have become infected as a result of contact with infected humans. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) As expected, monkeys and [great ape](/wiki/Great_ape) species such as [orangutans](/wiki/Orangutan) can also be infected with the COVID19 virus. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) Minks, which are in the [same family](/wiki/Weasel_family) ferrets, have been infected. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) Minks may be asymptomatic, and can also spread the virus to humans. [[461]](#cite_note-:9-461) Multiple countries have identified infected animals in [mink farms](/wiki/Mink_farm). [[462]](#cite_note-:10-462) [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark), a major producer of mink pelts, ordered the slaughter of all minks over fears of viral mutations, [[462]](#cite_note-:10-462) following an outbreak referred to as [Cluster 5](/wiki/Cluster_5). A vaccine for mink and other animals is being researched. [[462]](#cite_note-:10-462) Research International research on vaccines and medicines in COVID19 is underway by government organisations, academic groups, and industry researchers. [[463]](#cite_note-dhama-463) [[464]](#cite_note-zhang2020-464) The CDC has classified it to require a [BSL3](/wiki/BSL3) grade laboratory. [[465]](#cite_note-inlbg-465) There has been a great deal of COVID19 research, involving accelerated research processes and publishing shortcuts to meet the global demand. [[466]](#cite_note-Aristovnik_et_al._2020-466) As of December 2020 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19&action=edit), hundreds of [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trial) have been undertaken, with research happening on every continent except [Antarctica](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Antarctica). [[467]](#cite_note-467) As of November 2020 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19&action=edit), more than 200 possible treatments have been studied in humans. [[468]](#cite_note-468) Transmission and prevention research [Modelling](/wiki/Modeling_and_simulation) research has been conducted with several objectives, including predictions of the dynamics of transmission, [[469]](#cite_note-469) diagnosis and prognosis of infection, [[470]](#cite_note-470) estimation of the impact of interventions, [[471]](#cite_note-471) [[472]](#cite_note-472) or allocation of resources. [[473]](#cite_note-473) Modelling studies are mostly based on [compartmental models in epidemiology](/wiki/Compartmental_models_in_epidemiology), [[474]](#cite_note-474) estimating the number of infected people over time under given conditions. Several other types of models have been developed and used during the COVID19 pandemic including [computational fluid dynamics](/wiki/Computational_fluid_dynamics) models to study the flow physics of COVID19, [[475]](#cite_note-475) retrofits of crowd movement models to study occupant exposure, [[476]](#cite_note-476) mobility-data based models to investigate transmission, [[477]](#cite_note-477) or the use of [macroeconomic](/wiki/Macroeconomic) models to assess the economic impact of the pandemic. [[478]](#cite_note-478) Repurposed [antiviral drugs](/wiki/Antiviral_drug) make up most of the research into COVID19 treatments. [[479]](#cite_note-milken-479) [[480]](#cite_note-koch-480) Other candidates in trials [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) initiated the [Solidarity trial](/wiki/Solidarity_trial) to assess the treatment effects of some promising drugs: an [experimental drug](/wiki/Experimental_drug) [[481]](#cite_note-kai-481) [[482]](#cite_note-482) More than 300 active clinical trials are underway as of April 2020. [[68]](#cite_note-Sanders202022-68) Research on the antimalarial drugs [hydroxychloroquine](/wiki/Hydroxychloroquine) and [chloroquine](/wiki/Chloroquine) showed that they were ineffective at best, [[483]](#cite_note-20200526nytimes-483) [[484]](#cite_note-484) and that they may reduce the antiviral activity of remdesivir. [[485]](#cite_note-485) By May 2020 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=COVID-19&action=edit), France, Italy, and Belgium had banned the use of hydroxychloroquine as a COVID19 treatment. [[486]](#cite_note-486) In June, initial results from the randomised [RECOVERY Trial](/wiki/RECOVERY_Trial) in the United Kingdom showed that dexamethasone reduced mortality by one third for people who are critically ill on ventilators and one fifth for those receiving supplemental oxygen. [[487]](#cite_note-487) Because this is a well-tested and widely available treatment, it was welcomed by the WHO, which is in the process of updating treatment guidelines to include dexamethasone and other steroids. [[488]](#cite_note-488) [[489]](#cite_note-489) Based on those preliminary results, dexamethasone treatment has been recommended by the NIH for patients with COVID19 who are mechanically ventilated or who require supplemental oxygen but not in patients with COVID19 who do not require supplemental oxygen. [[490]](#cite_note-490) In September 2020, the WHO released updated guidance on using corticosteroids for COVID19. [[491]](#cite_note-WHO_guidance-491) [[492]](#cite_note-492) The WHO recommends systemic corticosteroids rather than no systemic corticosteroids for the treatment of people with severe and critical COVID19 (strong recommendation, based on moderate certainty evidence). [[491]](#cite_note-WHO_guidance-491) The WHO suggests not to use corticosteroids in the treatment of people with non-severe COVID19 (conditional recommendation, based on low certainty evidence). [[491]](#cite_note-WHO_guidance-491) The updated guidance was based on a meta-analysis of clinical trials of critically ill COVID19 patients. [[493]](#cite_note-493) [[494]](#cite_note-494) In September 2020, the [European Medicines Agency](/wiki/European_Medicines_Agency) (EMA) endorsed the use of dexamethasone in adults and adolescents from twelve years of age and weighing at least 40 kilograms (88 lb) who require supplemental oxygen therapy. [[495]](#cite_note-EMA_PR-495) [[496]](#cite_note-496) Dexamethasone can be taken [by mouth](/wiki/Oral_administration) or given as an injection or [infusion (drip) into a vein](/wiki/Intravenous). [[495]](#cite_note-EMA_PR-495) In November 2020, the US [Food and Drug Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration) (FDA) issued an emergency use authorisation for the investigational monoclonal antibody therapy [bamlanivimab](/wiki/Bamlanivimab) for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID19. [[497]](#cite_note-FDA_bamlanivimab_EUA-497) Bamlanivimab is authorised for people with positive results of direct SARS-CoV-2 viral testing who are twelve years of age and older weighing at least 40 kilograms (88 lb), and who are at high risk for progressing to severe COVID19 or hospitalisation. [[497]](#cite_note-FDA_bamlanivimab_EUA-497) This includes those who are 65 years of age or older, or who have chronic medical conditions. [[497]](#cite_note-FDA_bamlanivimab_EUA-497) In February 2021, the FDA issued an emergency use authorisation (EUA) for bamlanivimab and [etesevimab](/wiki/Etesevimab) administered together for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID19 in people twelve years of age or older weighing at least 40 kilograms (88 lb) who test positive for SARSCoV2 and who are at high risk for progressing to severe COVID19. The authorised use includes treatment for those who are 65 years of age or older or who have certain chronic medical conditions. [[498]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20210209-498) In April 2021, the FDA revoked the emergency use authorisation (EUA) that allowed for the investigational monoclonal antibody therapy bamlanivimab, when administered alone, to be used for the treatment of mild-to-moderate COVID19 in adults and certain paediatric patients. [[499]](#cite_note-FDA_PR_20210416-499) Cytokine storm A [cytokine storm](/wiki/Cytokine_storm) can be a complication in the later stages of severe COVID19. A cytokine storm is a potentially deadly immune reaction where a large amount of pro-inflammatory cytokines and [chemokines](/wiki/Chemokine) are released too quickly. A cytokine storm can lead to ARDS and multiple organ failure. [[500]](#cite_note-500) Data collected from Jin Yin-tan Hospital in Wuhan, China indicates that patients who had more severe responses to COVID19 had greater amounts of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines in their system than patients who had milder responses. These high levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines indicate presence of a cytokine storm. [[501]](#cite_note-501) [Tocilizumab](/wiki/Tocilizumab) has been included in treatment guidelines by China's [National Health Commission](/wiki/National_Health_Commission) after a small study was completed. [[502]](#cite_note-tocil-1-502) [[503]](#cite_note-tocil-2-503) It is undergoing a [Phase II](/wiki/Phase_IIb) non-randomised trial at the national level in Italy after showing positive results in people with severe disease. [[504]](#cite_note-504) [[505]](#cite_note-505) Combined with a serum ferritin blood test to identify a cytokine storm (also called cytokine storm syndrome, not to be confused with cytokine release syndrome), it is meant to counter such developments, which are thought to be the cause of death in some affected people. [[506]](#cite_note-tocil-5,6,8-506) The [interleukin-6 receptor](/wiki/Interleukin-6_receptor) (IL-6R) [antagonist](/wiki/Receptor_antagonist) was approved by the FDA to undergo a Phase III clinical trial assessing its effectiveness on COVID19 based on retrospective case studies for the treatment of steroid-refractory cytokine release syndrome induced by a different cause, [CAR T cell](/wiki/Chimeric_antigen_receptor_T_cell) [therapy](/wiki/Gene_therapy), in 2017. [[507]](#cite_note-CancerNetworkTocilizumabTrial-507) There is no randomised, controlled evidence that tocilizumab is an efficacious treatment for CRS. Prophylactic tocilizumab has been shown to increase serum IL-6 levels saturating the [blood-brain barrier](/wiki/Blood%E2%80%93brain_barrier), and exacerbating [neurotoxicity](/wiki/Neurotoxicity) while having no effect on incidence of CRS. [[508]](#cite_note-508) [Lenzilumab](/wiki/Lenzilumab), an anti-GM-CSF [monoclonal antibody](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibody), is protective in murine models for CAR T cell-induced CRS and neurotoxicity and is a viable therapeutic option due to the observed increase of pathogenic GM-CSF secreting T cells in hospitalised patients with COVID19. [[509]](#cite_note-509) Passive antibodies Transferring purified and concentrated [antibodies](/wiki/Immunoglobulin_therapy) produced by the immune systems of those who have recovered from COVID19 to people who need them is being investigated as a non-vaccine of action](/wiki/Mechanism_of_action) by which passive antibody therapy can mediate defence against SARS-CoV-2. The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralising antibodies. [[512]](#cite_note-:1-512) As of 8 August 2020, eight neutralising antibodies targeting the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 have entered clinical studies. [[513]](#cite_note-513) It has been proposed that selection of broad-neutralising antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV might be useful for treating not only COVID19 but also future SARS-related CoV infections. [[512]](#cite_note-:1-512) Other mechanisms, however, such as [antibody-dependant cellular cytotoxicity](/wiki/Antibody-dependent_cellular_cytotoxicity) or [phagocytosis](/wiki/Phagocytosis), may be possible. [[510]](#cite_note-pmid-32167489-510) Other forms of passive antibody therapy, for example, using manufactured monoclonal antibodies, are in development. [[510]](#cite_note-pmid-32167489-510) The use of passive antibodies to treat people with active COVID19 is also being studied. This involves the production of [convalescent serum](/wiki/Convalescent_serum), which consists of the liquid portion of the blood from people who recovered from the infection and contains antibodies specific to this virus, which is then administered to active patients. [[510]](#cite_note-pmid-32167489-510) This strategy was tried for SARS with inconclusive results. [[510]](#cite_note-pmid-32167489-510) An updated Cochrane review in May 2021 found high certainty evidence that, for the treatment of people with moderate to severe COVID19, convalescent plasma did not reduce mortality or bring about symptom improvement. [[511]](#cite_note-:20-511) There continues to be uncertainty about the safety of convalescent plasma administration to people with COVID19 and differing outcomes measured in different studies limits their use in determining efficacy. [[511]](#cite_note-:20-511) Bioethics Since the outbreak of the COVID19 pandemic, scholars have explored the [bioethics](/wiki/Bioethics), [normative economics](/wiki/Normative_economics), and [political theories](/wiki/Political_theories) of [healthcare policies](/wiki/Healthcare_policy) related to the public health crisis. [[514]](#cite_note-514) Academics have pointed to the moral distress of healthcare workers, ethics of distributing scarce healthcare resources such as ventilators, [[515]](#cite_note-515) and the global justice of vaccine diplomacies.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] The socio-economic inequalities between genders, [[516]](#cite_note-516) races, groups with disabilities, [[518]](#cite_note-518) communities, [[519]](#cite_note-519) regions, countries, [[520]](#cite_note-520) and continents have also drawn attention in academia and the general public. [...] Mask use has been found to be safe and is not associated with clinically significant impacts on respiration or gas exchange under most circumstances, except for intense exercise. The limited available data indicate no clear evidence that masking impairs emotional or language development in children. [I]n combination with other contextual cues, masks are unlikely to produce serious impairments of children's social interactions. A study of 2-year-old children concluded that they were able to recognize familiar words presented without a mask and when hearing words through opaque masks. Among children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD), interventions including positive reinforcement and coaching caregivers to teach mask-wearing have improved participants' ability to wear a face mask.
